15.text:
My name's Kerryn Wagg and  I work in the
paper and textiles conservation lab

19.text: here at the National Museum of Australia.

21.text:
I would like to begin today by
acknowledging the traditional owners

24.text: of the land on which we meet.

26.text: Today’s program is being run in

28.text:
conjunction with the
Museum Workshop exhibition

30.text:
that is currently on here at the
Museum where you can get an insight

34.text:
into the role that conservators play
in caring for the collection and

38.text:
getting objects ready for display. I
urge you all to visit the exhibition

41.text:
that is on in our temporary exhibition
gallery and visit our website too,

46.text:
because we have a lot of material
there to back up the exhibition.

51.text:
During today’s session
we will be looking

53.text:
at some of the
principles that will

54.text:
help you to care for
your own precious

56.text:
paper and textile items, such as
photo albums and wedding dresses.

60.text:
I will start by looking
at some issues

64.text:
and demonstrate some good ways
of putting photos into albums,

67.text:
before handing over to senior textiles
and paper conservator Carmela Mollica,

72.text:
who will discuss and demonstrate some
ways to care for your delicate textile

81.text:
So I would like to welcome
everyone here today.

84.text:
I would also like to extend a welcome to Kiama
who are crossing to us via a live link.

90.text:
Now I would like to hand
over to Michelle Hudson,

95.text:
the manager of library services at Kiama,
who is going to say a few words.

103.text:
Here at Kiama I would
like to say good afternoon to the

107.text:
audience down in
Canberra and a thank you

110.text:
to the National Museum of Australia
for providing us with the opportunity

114.text:
to participate in the class. We look
forward to sharing your experience

119.text: with our local community and look forward

121.text:
to participating in the question
and the answer session later on.

128.text:
So now I'd like to ask everyone to turn off
their mobile phones or turn them to silent.

133.text:
And Kiama can you please turn
your microphone to mute.

138.text:
There will be time for
questions at the end of the session

141.text:
so I would like you all to save
your questions until that time.

144.text:
We will cross to Kiama for
their questions first and

146.text:
then we will go to questions
from our Visions audience.

149.text:
I want to remind people that, if you do ask
a question during the Q&A session,

154.text:
you will be recorded for
museum related websites.

159.text:
So by asking your question, you are
giving your consent to being recorded.

163.text:
So the deterioration and damage
that we see in paper and textiles

168.text:
objects occurs because of inherent
and external factors.

172.text:
The inherent factors relate to the physical makeup
of objects which cause them to

176.text:
deteriorate, and these problems
can be hard to deal with.

179.text:
The external factors that
contribute to deterioration

182.text:
and damage are
easier to control.

185.text:
I would like to talk
about the issues as they

188.text:
relate to photographs,
and Carmela will

189.text:
discuss how they relate to garments.
However, many of the principles for

193.text:
caring for photos and garments, or
paper and textiles, are similar in

203.text:
environmental conditions for objects,
implementing good handling practices

208.text:
and having the correct types of
physical storage for items.

212.text:
When we talk about suitable environmental
conditions we really mean things like

217.text:
dark storage areas, because visible
and UV light can damage objects by

224.text:
You want to have stable relative humidity, one
that is not too high or too low.

231.text:
But when we say ‘stable’, that is because
paper and textiles are organic

235.text:
so they swell and contract with changes
in relative humidity.

240.text:
So you don’t want fluctuations
in a short period of time.

244.text:
Stable temperatures are also
important, temperatures that are

248.text: comfortable for humans are also good for your objects.

252.text:
When you have pest and mould outbreaks
in your paper and textiles items,

257.text:
it is often related to poor
environmental conditions

260.text:
so it’s good to look for the
causes of these outbreaks.

264.text:
By maintaining good housekeeping
and monitoring your objects,

268.text: you will keep these things at a minimum.

271.text:
That just means you want to keep your
storage areas clean and you want

275.text:
to check regularly for insect and
mould outbreaks.

280.text:
In your home, the centre of your home is probably best.
It’s the most stable environment.

287.text:
You want to avoid putting things in
your ceiling cavities and under your

291.text:
house and avoid putting things
against external walls as well.

295.text:
Good handling practices
are also very important.

300.text:
This means it’s important to plan
what you are doing before you start.

304.text: So you want to have enough space to work;

307.text:
you want to have the time
you need and the materials

309.text:
you need all at hand
before you get started.

314.text: It’s important to have clean hands or you can wear gloves.

318.text:
You can wear plastic gloves and
if you are wearing plastic gloves,

323.text:
you can look for close fitting
gloves that are good quality.

326.text:
You want them to be powder free.
Surgical gloves are good.

331.text:
You can wear cotton gloves
as well, but just be aware

335.text:
that you lose a bit of sensitivity of
touch with cotton gloves and

338.text: the threads can become caught on things.

342.text: Remove your jewellery as well before you start.

345.text:
When you are moving objects,it is important
to make sure that they are supported well.

350.text:
When you are storing objects
you want to have the

354.text:
physical storage
materials that you use

356.text:
to be ones that are not going to
react adversely with the objects.

361.text:
That just means you
want to look for things

363.text:
like archival and acid free storage
materials for your objects.

367.text:
We will look a bit more specifically
at some examples here today.

372.text:
I am going to look at some
examples for photographs.

376.text:
When we talk about photographs, true
photographs means writing with light.

381.text:
They have been processed using light
and they have a different chemical

387.text:
makeup and structure
to digital prints,

389.text:
which are often done on laser
or bubble jet printers.

392.text:
Some of the aspects of care are the same as
for all paper objects, but you do have the

400.text:
delicate emulsion layers and things
like that with a true photograph that

404.text:
you need to be very aware of when
you are handling and storing them.

409.text: So here we have... , when you are putting together new albums,

413.text:
you want to avoid sticking your
photographs down onto pages.

418.text:
Things like scrapbooking are
great and by all means do that,

421.text:
but use copies so you have always got
your archival or originals separate.

429.text:
This is one option you can use: so plastic
sleeves are great for photographs.

434.text:
What you want to look for is plastic that
is a polyester often sold as a mylar

443.text:
You can buy these from
conservation suppliers.

446.text:
We will tell you some at
the end of the session.

449.text:
They are great because
you can add them to albums

454.text:
and these ring-binding folios without actually
handling the photographs themselves.

461.text:
This is a great one that we have
here because it also got

464.text: a protective box which is another good thing to have with albums.

470.text: And that snaps into there for storage.

473.text:
Another great way to put your photos
into albums is to use photo corners.

482.text:
but you can also make your own - you
can use mylar plastic and fold it.

486.text:
Here I have a straight piece of mylar
plastic, but you can also use paper.

491.text:
So by folding it into a little triangle, you
can put double-sided sticky tape

496.text:
on the back and stick
that down to your pages.

501.text:
What you want to use for your pages is a
good acid-free medium to heavy weight card.

512.text:
You can stick those down and
put your photos in that way.

516.text:
If you have photos facing
each other in an album,

519.text:
you can interleave with things
like an archival text paper.

524.text:
It is often better to use a slightly
heavier paper than a tissue,

527.text:
because the tissue can become crumpled up
and cause physical damage to your photos.

534.text:
You can also buy albums, paper albums
that you can put photos into using

538.text:
photo corners, but again you
want to look for product labels

543.text:
that say they are archival
and things like that.

546.text: With photographs, you can also look for

549.text:
products that say they
have been PAT tested.

552.text:
That is a photo activity test
that is an international standard

556.text:
for products that
have all been tested

561.text:
done by the Image
Permanence Institute.

565.text:
If you don’t want to put
your photos into albums,

567.text:
you can put them into boxes. It’s good to
sort them into like-sized photographs.

573.text:
The best way to do it is to make an
enclosure for individual photographs.

580.text:
You can purchase these
three-flap or four-flap folders

583.text:
which have another flap at the top here
or you can make them yourself.

588.text:
That is a great way of
encapsulating your photographs

592.text:
and not having to
handle them physically.

594.text:
You can also put your labels on the paper
enclosure and you don’t have to label the photo.

600.text:
You want to avoid labelling photos
particularly with biros and inks.

605.text:
If you do feel that you want to
put a label on your photograph,

609.text:
put it on the back along a side and use
a soft pencil like a graphite B pencil.

617.text: I have an album here to show you.

619.text:
When you are handling your
albums, it is important

623.text:
to be aware of their
structure to support them.

628.text:
When you are transporting albums and even
individual photos, you can use

633.text:
a piece of heavy card to move things
to where you are working or a tray.

638.text:
When we open out an album, it is good to
have something to support it on.

645.text: You can use pillows at home.

647.text:
Two pillows that you have
stitched together in the centre

650.text: makes a good-shaped support for an album.

655.text:
This album has good features and
bad features. So it’s black paper.

659.text:
You want to avoid coloured papers,
particularly black paper, because it

664.text:
can have sulphur in it which can react
adversely with some of your photographs.

671.text:
Other things you want to avoid
are putting stacks of photographs

674.text:
together with paper clips; using
PVC plastic enclosures.

680.text:
You can often smell something
that has PVC in it.

685.text:
When you are interleaving, you
want to remember that you are

689.text:
putting extra strain, if its a
bound album, you're putting

692.text:
extra strain on the structure,
so you don’t want to put

696.text:
too much extra bulk into the
structure of a bound book.

702.text:
We will have some more
questions at the end.

705.text:
When you do see deterioration
with your photographs,

707.text:
it’s good to contact a conservator.
You can go to the AICCM, which is the

713.text:
Australian Institute for the
Conservation of Cultural Materials,

717.text:
website, and thats where you can
find conservators in your local area.

724.text: Now I will hand over to Carmela.

727.text:
Well like Kerryn said, paper and
textiles react quite closely to the

735.text:
same environments and problems
so I am not going to repeat

739.text: a lot of what Kerryn has said

741.text:
but concentrate on three
main ways I suppose of reducing some

752.text:
Today I have a wedding dress
here to use as an example.

756.text:
we either store them flat; we can store
them on a hanger; or we can roll.

762.text:
We will start with storing in a box
or it could be even in a drawer.

767.text:
Creasing is one of
the major causes

774.text:
of damage to the textile, especially
if it’s a silk which is quite fragile.

779.text:
Before we put anything away ,we
want to try to put it away clean

785.text:
because over time we find that,
while you may not see the stain

790.text:
or have spilt a glass of champagne on
your wedding dress or someone else has,

795.text:
and over time that stain will oxidise
with the impurities in there.

799.text:
So you do want to clean it
before you put it away.

802.text:
Once we have done all that,
the best way to reduce the creasing

809.text:
is to actually make special supports
that fit inside the dress really well.

817.text:
Here we can use acid-free tissue and
Kerryn mentioned about acidity in items.

825.text:
In this case we have used a
combination of dacron wadding,

829.text:
special supports that we
make ourselves and tissue.

834.text:
So if you don’t want to go
to the effort of making

837.text:
those special supports,
you can use your tissue.

842.text:
Because what we are trying
to do is make that fabric not

849.text:
create a crease but have a smooth
surface, we just crunch up our tissue.

856.text:
We don’t want that rough surface
against our fabric because again

860.text:
over time that can mould...
or the fabric

864.text:
can mould into that crease
and cause damage over time.

869.text:
We do want it to go
over a smooth surface.

873.text:
So we just get another piece
of tissue and roll it over.

886.text:
You end up with a smoother
area that you can then

889.text:
put inside your sleeve,or
your seams or your bodice.

894.text:
With the ones that we have here at the
moment, what we have done is actually

899.text:
created the shape of a sleeve or the
bodice using dacron wadding.

905.text:
And this you'll find in your...
if any of you are

909.text:
sewers you're probably familar with it,
or quilters, it’s used in quilting.

916.text:
We roll and create a shape,
whether it’s something like that

924.text:
or what we call a dacron
sausage, in different lengths

934.text:
You have your wadding inside rolled
to whatever shape and size you want.

940.text:
Then with the outer layer, again
we are looking at smooth fabric.

946.text:
In this case it’s 100 per cent polyester
as well, it’s like a lining fabric.

951.text:
But when we do use any of these
outer fabrics to provide the support,

957.text:
we do need to prewash them because in the
manufacturing process you have starches.

961.text:
Even getting them from the
manufacturer to your home

964.text:
there are other impurities
that can build up in the fabric.

968.text:
We want to have clean fabric
against our precious item,

973.text:
so they do get prewashed
in just a hot wash.

975.text:
We don’t add any detergents
or anything to it.

979.text:
Just a nice quick hot
wash will be perfect.

984.text:
Once we have done that, we
have created a long sausage

988.text: and feed that dacron into that roll.

992.text:
I then just have a gathering
thread around the end.

998.text: And if I can find my ends.

1013.text:
and tying it off so you end up
with a nice finish like that.

1019.text:
Again, we don’t use
anything that can catch onto

1024.text: the item that we are supporting.

1028.text:
This particular dress
doesn’t have a veil but,

1034.text:
if it did, again we could concertina
that in the box itself,

1039.text:
again using the rolls
and concertinaing it,

1043.text:
reducing the size of the veil,
or we can roll that veil

1052.text:
Again we have covered
this in acid-free tissue,

1054.text:
but you could cover that
in your fabric as well.

1057.text:
Once you have prepared
it, you need to make

1059.text:
sure that you have enough
space at either end so that

1064.text:
you handle the roll rather
than the textile itself.

1067.text:
And when rolling we
try to roll straight.

1071.text:
We don’t want to start getting a
sort of ladder effect happening,

1076.text:
because again that fabric over another
area can cause splitting of that textile.

1084.text:
so rolling and interleaving
its a very important thing

1087.text: to remember when we are folding

1090.text:
or rolling to interleave, whether it’s
with acid-free tissue or a fabric -

1097.text:
and in terms of fabric we also use
japara or calico or stretch knit but

1105.text:
again remembering to prewash
it - the reason why

1109.text:
we interleave is we don’t
want transference of dyes.

1113.text:
Sometimes a garment will
have hooks and eyes,

1117.text: or press studs or metal embroidery.

1120.text:
We are trying to reduce any corrosion
that may occur that we are not aware of

1129.text:
that could transfer onto the
other part of the garment.

1131.text:
You can see with the actual
train in this dress here,

1136.text:
we have provided
tissue along the folds

1140.text:
but also we have interleaved the different
layers with the tissue under there.

1151.text:
If you don’t have the space
for boxing, the other thing

1155.text: we can look at is hanging.

1160.text:
And with that we do  prepare coat
hangers in a special way

1166.text:
so that we are supporting the
garment on the shoulders.

1169.text:
When you are looking at wedding
gowns they are quite heavy

1172.text:
so we want to provide as much
support along the shoulders.

1177.text:
Sometimes we have to actually
attach tapes around the waist,

1182.text:
because that’s one of
our strongest areas,

1185.text:
just to reduce the weight
of the rest of the train.

1188.text:
Those tapes will just hang over
the coat hanger that you use.

1194.text:
That's only a small sized hanger, which
is probably not quite the right size

1199.text:
for a wedding gown, but you
can make them as large as ...

1209.text:
We look at the garment and pad
it - not overpad because you

1215.text:
don’t want to start splitting
and causing further damage -

1217.text:
just enough to
support the garment.

1220.text:
Again, to protect it
from the external

1224.text:
environments, whether
it’s from your wardrobe

1225.text:
or for travelling if you need to take
it elsewhere, providing a cover for it.

1231.text:
Again we have used par
silk or silk lining polyester but you

1236.text:
can use calico or japara –
anything that is pre-washed

1243.text:
You can see the length you may need
to go to for your wedding gown.

1248.text:
Ties, again, we don’t want to use
any metals or metallic zippers,

1255.text: press studs or hooks and eyes

1257.text:
because that’s another material we
are trying to avoid against fabrics.

1266.text:
So again just with with your
handling of your items:

1271.text:
don’t pick up from the shoulders
and support the bulk of the fabric.

1287.text:
There's a couple of wedding
dresses in there that

1289.text:
are quite heavy and the
bulk of it is on the bottom

1293.text:
- we are trying to avoid
creasing so that’s not quite

1296.text:
the right thing and also the coat hangers
aren’t providing the correct support.

1303.text:
They are also of a plastic
that can degrade over time.

1306.text:
If we do use a plastic
coat hanger we  just need

1310.text:
to make sure it’s polypropylene or
polyethylene rather than a PVC where

1315.text:
there are chlorides that can
damage the materials over time.

1320.text:
This particular cover is
a polyester so it’s fine,

1325.text:
but obviously the length of it is
not suitable for that garment.

1338.text:
... are commercial pillows that you can
use as well, if you don’t want to go to the

1342.text:
effort of making all these
doonas, that work just as well

1346.text:
cutting them smaller
to fit into the garment.

1350.text:
And in this dress here
we have lined the box,

1354.text: it's really just to provide another protection.

1359.text:
Also if we did need to lift
that item out of the box,

1363.text:
then we've got something
that we can use to support

1366.text:
- two people obviously
will need to lift that

1369.text:
out and put it onto
a table and so

1372.text:
on and then put it
back into there.

1375.text:
If you need to have something
cleaned, it’s best to

1386.text:
You can visit the AICCM website to
get some ideas there or our website.

1393.text:
Another good other little tip -
Kerryn talked about labelling.

1399.text:
Put a label and a photo
outside your box

1401.text:
or even on the outside
of your hanging bag

1407.text:
is always a good thing
so that you are not

1410.text:
having to rummage through your box to
remember what did I put in there.

1414.text:
You have a nice image on the
outside of that box.

1422.text: I will leave it at that.

1423.text:
And I am sure there
will be questions.

1426.text:
Now we will have our
question session.

1429.text:
We will be crossing to Kiama
first for their questions.

1432.text:
I want to remind people that
we can’t answer specific

1435.text:
questions about any
of your own objects

1437.text:
if you have them here today but we would
like to take some general questions.

1442.text:
If Kiama can unmute
their microphones

1445.text: and, if you are asking a question,

1447.text:
make sure you speak
into a microphone.

1461.text:
I just wondered with the garments,
if they can’t be washed,

1464.text:
can they be dry-cleaned, because a
lot of garments can’t be washed,

1470.text:
especially with embroidery
and things on them?

1475.text:
That's right. Normally
a lot of the garments

1479.text:
do have a garment label that
will give you an idea of if it can

1485.text:
be hand washed or dry-cleaned only.
You can dry clean.

1489.text:
Obviously we can’t recommend
a dry cleaner in Kiama

1498.text:
But visiting your dry cleaner
and asking them questions

1504.text:
about what their processes are
and how do they deal with

1508.text:
items that have lots of
embroidery, metallic thread

1515.text:
or any surface decoration
and how they deal with that

1520.text:
that'll give you an idea whether you
can trust them with your objects.

1525.text:
Certainly we do dry clean
here at the Museum.

1530.text:
If we can manage the
size,we do it ourselves

1532.text:
under extraction
hoods and so on.

1537.text:
But you can take things out
commercially and have them dry cleaned.

1548.text:
I notice that all the
photographs are loose.

1551.text:
I have some photographs that
have been stuck to black albums

1556.text:
and then dispersed amongst relatives
as people have passed away.

1560.text: What do you do with those photographs?

1563.text:
The photographs are physically
stuckdown to the black pages?

1572.text:
You don’t want to try to remove photos that
have been physically stuck down yourself.

1577.text:
I would say that in that situation it
is best to take them to a conservator

1581.text:
just so they can actually look
at what condition they are in,

1584.text:
whether that is causing
damage to them.

1588.text:
And they can give you some advice
on what you can do about that.

1601.text:
I think that might be all the questions
we have here at Kiama. Thank You.

1608.text:
Now we will take
questions from the room.

1611.text:
Someone will be coming
around with a microphone.

1613.text:
Please wait until you have the
microphone before you ask a question.

1618.text:
My question is about old
fabrics that sometimes develop

1622.text:
little brown marks
indiscriminately across them.

1625.text:
Is there anything that can be
done about those brown marks?

1629.text:
Brown marks could be what
we call a foxing or could

1633.text:
just cellulose degradation
over time relating to how

1636.text:
has it been stored or is it from the
materials that it’s been against?

1641.text:
Sometimes you can reduce
that; sometimes you can’t.

1647.text:
If you look at this garment
closely, you will see

1652.text:
there are still stains
and it has been treated.

1655.text: Our aim is to reduce what the

1658.text:
components of that stain are and not
necessarily try to remove the actual

1665.text:
colour because sometimes
you can’t reduce that.

1670.text:
Without knowing what the item is
or how that stain has come about,

1676.text:
it’s difficult to provide
any one answer to it.

1681.text:
But it may have occurred from the
materials they were stored in

1686.text:
or whether it’s in a drawer because
the timbers also emit vapours

1693.text:
that can cause damage to
the staining on a garment

1697.text:
or was it from having
being worn in the past?

1703.text:
I suppose if you are concerned about
something, again visit the AICCM website

1709.text:
and someone can give you some
separate detailed advice there.

1733.text:
I have a question about
conserving letters.

1736.text:
Would you go through the same process
as photographs to restore old letters?

1743.text:
Well, paper objects,
there are some general

1747.text:
principles about caring
for your paper objects.

1750.text:
With letters and things
like that, a lot of the time

1753.text:
some of the damage that you see is from
the physical handling particularly

1758.text:
It’s often a good idea to store
those letters flat, if you can.

1763.text:
And plastic sleeves are a
really good option for letters,

1769.text:
because you don’t have to
handle the paper itself

1772.text:
but you can still read
them and things like that.

1776.text:
The storage conditions
are very similar.

1782.text:
and just having clean hands when you
do handle them and things like that.

1787.text:
And I suppose if it is
folded, sorry to interrrupt,

1789.text:
not forcing the letter open because that’s
where you can

1797.text:
Yes, if it’s already folded, but
don’t fold them up to store them.

1805.text:
My question is related to
vintage and antique clothing.

1809.text:
I'm interested to know, and firstly
you mentioned that the Museum

1813.text:
has dry cleaners who you use or
whether that is someone internally.

1819.text:
And also I have quite a few garments from the
1920s through the Victorian era and,

1825.text:
as you are aware, they didn’t have
deodorants and quite a few of them

1829.text:
have perspiration marks bearing
from faint to quite dark.

1834.text:
What would be your advice in relation to
conserving garments with that sort of thing;

1839.text:
and also with the metal weights in
the bottom of the gowns, whether you

1848.text:
Metals obviously react to the environments
that we were mentioning earlier.

1854.text:
We need to look at the whole picture,
where they are stored and the environment.

1861.text:
Here at the Museum we don’t
remove metal weights unless

1865.text:
they have already caused a
considerable amount of damage

1869.text:
or they have rusted and then we
will consider something like that.

1872.text:
If there is no sign of anything
having happened, then looking at the

1882.text:
environment which we store them in and
having that consistent temperature

1886.text:
and rate of humidity so that that metal
doesn’t start to corrode and so on.

1893.text:
With dry cleaners, we dry clean items
ourselves here if we are able to;

1903.text:
And again similar to what I
was saying earlier,

1906.text:
we are familiar with some of the dry
cleaners and we do quiz them.

1911.text:
A simple thing as we like
our items dry cleaned

1915.text:
first thing in the morning, for example, so
that they've gone through a solution,

1920.text:
a fresh solution, rather
than at the end of the day

1923.text:
when a whole lot of other items have
already been dry cleaned.

1929.text:
We do a lot of testing before we send them
out to dry cleaners ourselves

1934.text:
to make sure that they will cope
with the solvents that they use.

1946.text:
I have a large number
of old fabrics.

1951.text:
With some of them I can tell
what type of fabric it is,

1955.text:
but with others it’s very difficult
to do that, to establish.

1960.text: Do you have any pointers or any....

1963.text:
Any pointers or any ways that I
possibly could establish

1970.text:
So you are talking about what
fibre compositions they are?

1974.text:
The best way to identify fibre is
looking at it under a microscope,

1980.text:
and that’s what we use here at the
Museum just taking very small fibre.

1987.text:
A lot of these analytical
techniques are destructive

1994.text:
so obviously we don’t
want to go down that path.

2000.text:
Just a very, very small
fibre sample is enough

2005.text:
for us to determine what fibre it
is under the microscope.

2011.text:
If you work with fabrics,
just feel and handle.

2016.text:
And again, make sure your hands are
clean when you do that and so on.

2022.text:
The microscope
is a good friend of ours.

2036.text:
I have a double-barrelled
question, if I may.

2038.text:
The first part of it concerns
off-the-shelf photo albums.

2041.text:
Can you give us a comment
about their efficacy and

2046.text:
whether or not they should
be used or not used?

2048.text:
In relation to that, should we be
treating photos that a century or older

2054.text:
differently to the manner in which
we treat more recent photos in

2058.text:
relation to the paper and what
not that is used for them?

2062.text:
Certainly, well you can get some good
quality photo albums that you can purchase.

2068.text:
Again, you want to look for either
the sleeves or paper that is a

2074.text:
good quality archival acid-free paper
and again avoiding coloured papers.

2081.text:
There is a few suppliers
that you can go to.

2087.text:
There are archival suppliers in
Australia that the general public can

2093.text:
also purchase albums
or anything from.

2097.text:
I can list them out or, if you want to
come and see us at the end of the session,

2101.text:
I am happy
to give them to you.

2103.text: But you can like Kerryn said, some of those

2107.text: commercial - some of them are fine.

2110.text:
so just look for things like,..
that they are..., I mean

2113.text:
if you are going for the
sleeves that it is a

2114.text:
polyester or polypropylene
and that your papers are acid free.

2119.text: They often will say archival quality.

2121.text:
Even you know scrapbooking
suppliers will often say

2124.text:
that they have passed the
PAT photo activity test.

2127.text:
So a lot of products will
have information on them.

2133.text:
With your older photographs,
certainly they are delicate photos

2139.text:
are unstable in their nature so you
do have deterioration.

2145.text:
I mentioned very briefly inherent
factors and with true photographs

2149.text:
there are a lot of inherent
factors that are going to cause

2152.text:
them to deteriorate over time and
chemicals within their structure.

2156.text:
So you do need to be quite
careful about the materials that

2158.text:
you put in contact with true
photographs because they do interact.

2163.text:
As I mentioned, black pages
will often contain sulphur,

2168.text:
which interacts adversely
with the silver which is

2171.text:
used in most of the older
photographs and things like that

2176.text:
So you do need to be extra careful
with your older photographs.

2179.text:
There is often a lot of damage
that you do see already.

2183.text:
If it’s something inherent
in it that is deteriorating,

2187.text:
it’s good to take even a digital
snap, if you don’t have negatives,

2190.text:
of the way it looks now so
that you can at least record it

2202.text:
You have almost answered
my question but it was:

2205.text:
how do I identify what the plastic is,
if it’s polyethylene, PVC or whatever?

2211.text:
Perhaps if I have received something
that no longer has credentials on it.

2217.text:
Well PVC you can often
smell, so that’s a good tip.

2220.text:
It's got a very,
very strong smell.

2223.text:
It’s like a chlorine because
it is polyvinyl chloride.

2229.text:
There is a simple test where you
apply a hot needle to the plastic

2241.text:
If you get a green flame that indicates
there are chlorides present.

2250.text:
If you are looking for
products, go for the ones

2254.text:
where it tells what
it is on the product.

2256.text:
A lot of the commercial ones will
tell you what the plastic present is

2260.text:
on the packaging or at least you
can find ones that do tell you that

2266.text: and in that way you are sure.

2267.text:
Because if you have products
that say nothing about

2269.text:
what’s in them, then you
have no true way of knowing.

2273.text:
Also sometimes the feel of
the PVC is quite crisp and

2277.text:
crunchy as if it is almost
going to snap and break;

2282.text:
whereas with a polypropylene or
polyethylene it's a softer material.

2289.text:
Also your food containers, containers that
you can are going to store

2293.text:
food in them, not your $2 ones but your
Tupperwares and things like that,

2298.text:
that’s a stable material that you can
use to store your albums and things in.

2316.text:
Just in relation to the
storage and plastic,

2320.text:
you can get those
big plastic boxes

2322.text:
- I see there is a plastic tray with
a lid underneath the box there;

2329.text:
I am not necessarily refering to that
- but you can get big storage boxes

2333.text:
You know what I'm talking about.
There are a lot of them around.

2337.text:
And big enough to take
volumes of photo albums.

2341.text:
Are they suitable for storing
things such as this in?

2345.text:
Are they made from the
appropriate plastic?

2347.text:
Most of them are polypropylene
so they are suitable.

2353.text:
Just like I have done here with the
garment where I have lined it,

2358.text:
just to give you that extra
protection, I suppose, lining that

2364.text:
box with a sheet of clean
calico or a white cotton sheet

2370.text:
that is obviously clean
and been prewashed.

2374.text:
That provides another
barrier, but certainly

2379.text:
they are suitable and you can
seal them and prevent insects.

2382.text: It gives you that extra protection.

2384.text:
So it is quite good to put your albums
into boxes and storage containers.

2392.text:
We’ve got some embroidered
baby garments from

2397.text:
the mid-1800s which have been
stored rolled in tissue paper

2406.text:
Is there anything I could do to reverse
that or to prevent it becoming worse?

2416.text:
Do you have any suggestions about
baby clothes that are quite old?

2422.text:
They are cotton, you know, white
cotton, quite sturdy fabric

2429.text:
with a lot of very
fine embroidery.

2433.text:
Very similar to what we have been
talking about rolling a garment,

2439.text:
You know a three-dimensional garment having
that rolled you are creating creases

2444.text:
and over time damage there so it is best
not to have it rolled

2449.text:
but just laying it flat in a
box or something like that.

2455.text:
In terms of the yellowing, it depends
on what’s caused that yellowing.

2462.text:
Sometimes it’s just general what
we call cellulose degradation,

2467.text:
which is the inherent
nature of the cotton

2470.text:
that just discolours over
time, and that can be reduced.

2478.text:
But you have embroidery on there
so there are other issues

2483.text:
It’s really hard to give
an answer on that one.

2488.text:
It might again be best to
visit the AICCM website

2493.text:
consult with a conservator and
obtain their advice on that.

2499.text:
The long christening
robe we have hung rather

2502.text:
like you described for the wedding
dress and that has done better than

2507.text:
the short baby garments that have
been rolled up in tissue paper.

2511.text:
Fabric with fabric is one of the
better materials to use in terms

2521.text:
It probably wouldn’t be a good idea
to try to reverse the yellowing.

2533.text:
Sometimes a wet clean
is suitable for that,

2541.text:
But I can’t recommend that process
because I haven’t seen it.

2558.text:
So far we have been talking about
textiles that are mainly woven.

2562.text:
Are there any special issues
around knitted garments

2568.text:
Knitted garments would be treated in the
same way, so you would pad them out

2577.text:
Obviously make sure that you clean them,
if you can, before you put them away,

2582.text:
especially woollen garments where
you would pack them away over the

2585.text:
winter break.., over the summer
sorry, and bring them out in winter.

2590.text:
You need to make
sure they are clean.

2593.text:
It’s mainly for insects because
they do like to eat on foods

2600.text:
that are present in
the garment as stains.

2607.text:
What was the other question? Repellents?
Moth repellents.

2613.text:
I think Kerryn mentioned earlier, the
best thing to avoid, or try to reduce

2621.text:
insects entering your home or in a
particular area is good housekeeping.

2627.text:
Making sure that areas are
clean, not having little corners

2635.text:
that insects can crawl
into because that will be

2640.text: nice and yummy for them there.

2645.text:
The Museum has to deal with
insects just like I do at home:

2649.text:
And we do, we check; we go around
in the buildings and make sure

2655.text:
there aren’t any
issues with insects.

2658.text:
Sticky traps. You can use
some perimeter sprays.

2665.text:
And again, you know some people
don’t like to fumigate their places

2669.text:
but a lot of the pyrethrin
sprays that are used

2672.text:
are natural and obviously
aren’t harmful to individuals.

2682.text:
We don’t put anything specific
in a box with a garment.

2688.text:
Naphthalene was one that
was used over the years.

2691.text:
It is certainly not a good thing
to be using with your garments.

2698.text:
Naphthalene is also no good for us as
humans so try to avoid anything with that.

2711.text:
We have some linen that is around
about 100 years, or more, old.

2716.text:
I was looking at it the other
day and noticed that there

2720.text:
are some little cracks and
places where threads have

2726.text:
worn through and obviously
historically over the years

2731.text: some of these have been mended.

2734.text:
I wondered with these new ones
that I have discovered,

2737.text:
should I try to mend them; and,
if so, how should I do it?

2747.text:
Should I use a sewing machine
or should I do it by hand

2750.text:
with silk thread or should
I just leave it alone?

2753.text:
Probably just leave it alone. Are they
linen pieces that you are using or..?

2760.text:
One of them is a big
damask tablecloth which

2764.text:
we have always used
on Christmas Day.

2768.text:
Another one is a beautiful
hand-embroidered bedspread,

2774.text:
which very, very occasionally
we give ourselves

2778.text:
a treat and decorate
our bed with it.

2781.text:
I would absolutely hate to make things
worse by leaving an unmended tear or hole.

2793.text:
I suppose, we don’t use a
sewing machine to mend tears...

2798.text:
it is usually hand stitching. Again, it’s
going to come down to you – And skills.

2805.text:
Yes, and the significance of
the item and things like that.

2815.text:
In some of the ones that have
already been mended in the past

2819.text:
- not very well, I may say -
what thread would I use?

2826.text:
We normally try to keep the same, so
if it’s a cotton or if it’s a linen,

2833.text:
we try and use the same thread
as what the item is made of,

2839.text:
if that thread is going to
be suitable for that repair.

2843.text:
Sometimes we do need to use a
polyester thread for whatever reason.

2848.text:
We make that call depending
on what we are repairing.

2853.text:
If it’s a silk item we try
to use silk for that repair.

2857.text:
But again it depends on
where and what the item is.

2864.text:
One other question. We have
a fan dating from the 1890s

2871.text:
it's silk with ivory sticks and some
of the sticks have become detached.

2881.text:
There is a lot of cracking of the
silk, and I realise that’s past help.

2891.text:
should I just leave it alone
and not play with it and say,

2895.text:
‘Well that’s sad but it’s
broken,’ or is there anything

2898.text:
I can do to prevent
further deterioration?

2906.text:
Has the guards on
them been stuck down

2909.text:
or are they stitched?
Or the adhesive has ..?

2914.text:
I can’t provide any answers here
and it might be again something

2919.text:
that a conservator will
need to have a look at.

2921.text:
The less handling of that item
would be beneficial for it,

2926.text:
so I suppose providing whether
it’s a tray or a small box for it

2934.text:
but you can still handle
and view the item

2936.text:
but you're not
actually holding it.

2942.text:
Is it closed or open -
that’s the other thing.

2948.text:
It’s closed and it’s
wrapped in tissue.

2951.text:
I always had the idea that I
would like to have it framed

2954.text:
but that’s probably
not a good idea?

2957.text:
They do require a
special support.

2960.text:
Obviously when you open up
a fan it’s not straight

2967.text:
and won’t sit flat on a bench, so
you do need to build up the area

2976.text:
underneath the fan to
support it in that frame.

2980.text: But it is possible to do that.

2983.text:
Is there anywhere one could get
advice from as to how that

3000.text:
Yes, AICCM.org.au and there’s
actually a link that says

3006.text:
‘find a conservator’ or
"conservator" or something like that

3009.text:
and then they have a list of
conservators in every city.

3013.text:
The Yellow Pages as well. Some
conservators advertise in there as well.

3019.text:
There are some framers that can help
there and normally they will be

3024.text:
advertised on the website
or in the Yellow Pages.

3031.text:
I wanted to ask a question
about photographs again.

3034.text:
Our 1960s wedding photographs
are in a 1960s folio

3039.text: with the plastic sheet over the top.

3047.text:
Are we talking about the
so-called magnetic photos where

3050.text:
you have the sticky strips and
then the plastic over the top?

3053.text:
No, I think they were probably stuck
in, there was some sort – yes, there was

3056.text:
some sort of adhesive and then the
plastic sheet went over the top.

3059.text:
Yeah. So they are often
referred to as magnetic albums

3063.text:
and they use the same sorts of
adhesives that you see in sticky-tape

3066.text:
so they are not good
for your photos.

3069.text:
Those adhesives go through different
phases as they deteriorate.

3074.text:
They will become very sticky; they will
migrate into the paper fibres

3077.text:
of the photographs; and
then they start to change

3080.text:
colour so they go yellow, then dark
orange and turn very hard.

3085.text:
Now when you've got photos that
are already in those albums,

3089.text:
it’s best not to try to
remove them yourself because

3091.text:
they do quite stuck quite
firmly and in trying

3095.text:
to remove them you will
likely cause further damage.

3097.text:
It is good to take those to a conservator
to have them remove them for you.

3101.text:
But again you can take a
digital photo of your photo and

3109.text:
then make up a new album
and at least record them

3112.text:
as they are now before
they deteriorate further.

3120.text:
Okay, we've just got time
for one more question.

3128.text:
Kerryn, I wonder if you
had any particular advice

3131.text:
about photographic slides. We have
a large collection of slides from

3136.text:
the 1950s and possibly early 1960s.
They are medium format slides.

3142.text:
A lot of them are glass encased and they
are starting to fall apart, becoming

3147.text:
detached from the paper, and they
have a lot of dust on them.

3150.text:
We want to know what
we should be doing for

3155.text:
Well, often with slides it’s good
to store them vertically.

3158.text:
A lot of conservation suppliers will
sell enclosures for keeping slides in

3164.text:
with different formats
for the different size

3167.text:
slides so it’s good to
get those for them.

3172.text:
You don’t want the weight compiling
when you are storing them

3178.text:
horizontally if you are
storing them in stacks.

3183.text:
Interleaving again is
a good thing to do.

3186.text:
But when you start to see damage
already, take them to a conservator

3190.text:
to give you some advice on fixing them
and dealing with those issues of damage.

3198.text:
With dust, is there
anything better we can

3200.text:
do other than hit them
with a dust blower?

3203.text:
That’s a good way
to deal with dust.

3206.text:
But if you have them in
enclosures where the dust

3209.text:
can’t get to them any more, that would
be the best way to deal with dust.

3217.text: Okay, well I'd like to thank everyone again.

3220.text:
So thank you, Kiama, for being part of
today and thank you

3224.text:
everyone who has come
to see the session.
